history.content:
I personally wouldn't if you're interested in understanding both classes well. CS61C is already quite important and time-consuming by itself, but CS170 is extremely important if you want to smash SWE interviews in the future. An extremely good understanding of 170 will serve you really, really well on interviews. If you get an A in the class you honestly don't need to study very hard for interviews... I got a B in the class and ended up not studying for the interviews, but still managed to get an offer from a Big 4 based off what I learned in the class.

I took both in the same semester with two breadths and I thought that was already pretty rough. No regrets not taking an additional tech. I think 61C was about 12 hours a week and 170 was about 15-20. 170 was pretty fun at the beginning, boring in the middle, and then got super fun at the end esp: with the big project. Two 3-unit breadths or one light tech is my suggestion. 

186 might be my suggestion. The projects have gotten rougher in the last semesters, but lots of stuff in 170 and 61C applies and supports your studies in 186 and vice-versa. I don't think we really have any more "easy" techs. Maybe E120 if you want a low-commitment (but not necessarily easy) 3-unit class that counts as an UD elective for L&S and want to learn about businesses and personal finance.

I took both in the same semester with two breadths and I thought that was already pretty rough. No regrets not taking an additional tech. I think 61C was about 12 hours a week and 170 was about 15-20. That being said, 170 was one of the most fun classes I've taken at Cal! Also either the interviews coincidentally got a lot easier after taking the class, or I got a LOT better at them (was passing Big 4 interviews) without additional studying--I'm pretty sure it's the 170!

children.subject: Also 61c with Garcia is super nice, and having a project course with a math course is a solid combo.
Counter point to above - haven't taken 170 and got big 4 internship from networking and doing a bit of leetcode.
170 wasn’t needed for my interviews that I didn’t get from leetcode.

Oh yeah and I forgot to add, it can be an absolute GPA tanker for more practically inclined students since it's a theoretical class. So if you really wish to take it AND take multiple techs, you can just P/NP it, and it won't matter for industry.

Agreed! It's leaning towards more math and theory. I regret taking this class since I probably could have better used my time to grind leetcode for interview instead of suffering for a semester not understanding the material. But definitely take this class if you're interested in CS theory.

170 is pretty useless actually, as long as you grind leetcode and understand how to IMPLEMENT certain concepts that pop up in 170 like DP and Greedy in the context of frequently asked interview questions. Other than that 170 is pretty much a waste of time. But if you are going to take it, don't take it with more than 61C.
Depends on what area you plan to research on. In general, yes, mastery of algorithms is essential for almost any field in CS.
is 170 important for someone interested in grad school?
What about Data 100 or EE 16B with no lab as the third tech?

history.content:
I have taken 61A, 61B, 70, and Math 54. I plan on taking 61C and 170 next semester either, but am unsure whether to add another tech to my schedule.

How difficult is the workload for 61C + 170? Additionally, what are some suggestions for courses whose workload would fit well with 61C and 170?
history.subject: 61c + 170 + another tech?
